Modification events related to critical.Data: Windows Event ID 5136, Windows Event ID 5137, Windows Event ID 5138, Windows Event ID 5139, Windows Event ID 5141
Modification events related to critical.Action: Monitor Windows Event IDs 5136, 5137, 5138, 5139, 5141 on Domain Controllers for changes to critical GPO objects (e.g., Default Domain Policy, Default Domain Controllers Policy). Identify changes affecting software installation, script execution, user rights assignment, or security options. Investigate changes originating from non-administrative accounts or service accounts.

Changes to domain trust relationships or.Data: Windows Event ID 307, Windows Event ID 510
Changes to domain trust relationships or.Action: Monitor relevant logs (Windows Event ID 307, 510) on ADFS/Identity Servers for modifications to domain trust settings, federation settings, or authentication methods (Managed to Federated). Identify changes originating from unusual accounts or locations. Use frequency analysis to identify rare configuration changes.

Modification events for GPOs immediately.Data: Windows Event ID 5136, Windows Event ID 5137, Windows Event ID 5138, Windows Event ID 5139, Windows Event ID 5141, Windows Event ID 4688
Modification events for GPOs immediately.Action: Correlate GPO modification events (Windows Event ID 5136-5141) with subsequent process creation events (Windows Event ID 4688) on domain machines or servers, looking for suspicious executables or scripts launched shortly after a GPO update. Use time series analysis to identify unusual timing between policy changes and subsequent actions.

Rapid sequence of policy modification an.Data: Windows Event ID 5136, Windows Event ID 5137, Windows Event ID 5138, Windows Event ID 5139, Windows Event ID 5141, Windows Event ID 307, Windows Event ID 510
Rapid sequence of policy modification an.Action: Monitor sequence of policy modification (Windows Event ID 5136-5141) and deletion/undeletion/reversion events (Windows Event ID 5138, 5139, 5141, 307, 510) on Domain Controllers/Identity Servers. Identify rapid back-and-forth changes to the same policy objects. Analyze the time delta between modification and reversion using descriptive statistics (e.g., mean, min, max, stdev) to identify changes occurring much faster than normal administrative procedures.
